review_title: Avoid the hospice/home health/hospice house departments
job_title: Hospice RN Case Manager in Olathe, KS
pros: The benefits and retirement weren't bad, the pay was comparable to others in the market. They let us do the jobs we were hired for, up until January of 2022 when things started going WAY Downhill.
cons:
For the two years of the pandemic the home hospice group had a team that held the department together, even when the supervisor was laid off in June of 2020. We grew the department by 30% despite the pandemic and only one staff member turned over. We were able to carry out our duties to the point of having a deficiency free survey once the worst of the pandemic was over.

We survived as a mostly intact team through 5 transitions at the director level. In January of 2022 they allowed the home health supervisor to step into the role of director over Hospice/Hospice House/Home Health. Her background and focus was all profit all the time. This wasn't entirely her fault as the directives originated with the VP of nursing but unlike her predecessors in the director role, she had no interest in standing up for the staff or the patients. This is probably why we went through so many...

In April of 2022 they decided to increase the expected number of visits a day for a home hospice nurse from 3-5 to 7 or 8. This is completely impractical and unsafe based on the nature of the hospice goals of care. This was addressed with management and staff was actively told to "shut up and do as you are told" because the expectation was not going to change. 

Unfortunately the director had no experience in hospice and tried to make it run exactly like home health and had no interest in learning about hospice beyond lecturing staff about how to make things "more profitable". 

These are people's family members and they are going through one of the hardest experience many of them have ever faced and they are being told they can't have all the supplies, visits or support they need to get through it because of lack of staffing. They are facing having visits cut to the bone, inexperienced staff, and staff with a lower level licensure being sent instead of RN's. They went from one supervisor who also worked in the field, and four trained RNs who had been in the field ranging from 1 year to 15 years and over the last 4 months they have gone down to one Hospice house supervisor and two very inexperienced hospice RN's and a few LPN's who are doing the majority of the work. 

The Director who allowed this to happen, and who actively forced out the experienced staff is still there and has been allowed to bully, berate, and terrorize her staff to the point of multiple HR complaints being filed that the main HR staff won't do anything about. She retaliates against anyone who speaks out against her and actively gets out any staff member who isn't one of her sycophants.

 If you are looking to get into hospice, I cannot in good conscience recommend that anyone apply here. I have been in the industry since 2009 and have never had a situation quite this bad. They will work you to death and then throw you to the wolves when you prioritize anything but profits and productivity.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator (HR Coordinator) in Olathe, KS

pros: I really cannot think of one reason why anyone would want to work there.
cons: Poor Management. Your only a number. Continued to add more responsibilities. New CEO Took away bonuses. The CEO ADVERTISE each month one employee will win a car, it was a match box car. Extremely unorganized.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Olathe, KS
pros: I really like the CEO. He listens and cares. Decent benefits. Some great co workers that will be my friend for life.
cons: Management is horrible. Turn over is terrible and this is because of the horrible management. Management needs classes on how to manage. I am not sure where they find these people that bully, are non compassionate, and bring there own personal situations up to try to prove that your situations do not matter. Very nonprofessional. Cardiology is amazing aside from the lousy management. The management drains you of your self worth and motivation.

pros: Unit has good teamwork, coworkers help one another, scheduling is good (given shifts you request). Lazy workers have been fired more frequently every year instead of it taking about 5 years to occur like before. Management is openly now asking for feedback which is good.
cons: Management (over 50 managers were just fired due to budget cuts) is out of touch, high staffing ratios (1:5-6 RN to pt, 1:8-16/17 PCT to pts (especially bad on weekends) they discovered they could increase during pandemic without any lawsuits so they've kept them high bc $$, housekeeping is unreliable and rarely shows up (think things are cleaned once daily at MOST, not every few hours., Yuck). Pay is mediocre- if it were better, turnover would be reduced. PTO not approved for nurses: guess what- if you don't approve it, they'll call in sick because they have obligations and you'll still be short regardless. Mass exodus of nurses in the last 6 months.

review_title: Run don't walk away from this CEO
pros: Work is close to home
cons:
Fomer Ceo was awesome. He valued his employees making sure staffing was sufficient and giving yearly bonuses to all employees. New ceo was hand picked by previous retiring ceo. He picked poorly. New ceo has amassed chaos within by giving extremely poor, highly priced insurance. Last year he asked for 100 FTE positions to volunteer for buyouts or retirement. He got 150 volunteers. He wasn't done there. After, he eliminated 30 more positions including management. This caused 8 managers to quit. Just found out that a new Neurologist was hired from Arizona for a price tag of 25 million. This new Dr does 1 procedure, just one. He required a new state of the art unit and a separate entrance for his convenience. Staff is so short staffed it is a safety issue. All employees doing patient care are beyond stressed out. There is no one to call for help as everyone has either been let go or has quit. 
I do not recommend working at OMC. Wait til the community finds out their once beloved hospital standards are intentionally not being met.

job_title: Patient Care Tech in Olathe, KS
pros: Olathe Medical Center/Olathe Health reached out to me and sent me a card to their open house for CNAs and gave me a chance to talk to the RNs on different floors and get a feel for what each unit has to offer. The online application was easy and very user friendly. Call back time was incredibly quick and I was notified within three days. Staff has been incredibly helpful, whether it's helping an individual locate where they need to go, training new hires, or caring for their customers. Hours are flexible as I am a PRN and every employee can requests shifts if they need more hours without feeling like they absolutely have to.
cons: There aren't many cons when it comes to working at Olathe Medical Center/Olathe Health. The orientation period for patient care techs involves a day of computer heavy learning that makes learning the online charting system seem rather overwhelming at first but once you reach your home unit, you will be taught the more intricate side of the system and it become less overwhelming. Outside of that minor issue my time as an Olathe Health employee has been a great experience.

job_title: RN Float Pool in Olathe, KS
pros: Everyone is very accepting and helpful. I felt welcome and appreciated from the very beginning. The education/orientation process is amazing. Brea makes it a breeze. She is very kind, patient and knowledgeable. OMC is a great place to work with opportunities, competitive wages and great benefits. Friendly people and no drama. The managers are awesome to work with and listen to staff. Great support system in place. Employees have the opportunity for advancement and to work extra shifts. Cross training and working in other departments is available. Staff to patient ratio has been great. I’ve never felt overwhelmed or overworked. There are always or staff to assist and answer questions or concerns. The doctors and hospitals have been easy to work with. I truly enjoy working at OMC and am not disappointed with my opportunity to work there!
cons: I really haven’t in negatives or cons! I’ve worked over 3 months and this has been one of the best hospitals if not the best hospital to work for!

pros: I worked in the hospital and clinics. For the most part the frontline employees truly care about the job and patients.
cons:
Management is horrible. The CEO's favorite line is "Everyone is replaceable ". I was told that by a VP who thought it was a good thing. Doctors and nurses are treated like royalty while all other staff is disposable. 
There is a terribly negative culture that is pervasive throughout the entire organization. The negativity starts from the top down. The IT department resigned in mass twice. They can't keep good staff in any department. As long as senior management remains stagnant and in the old school business model, this health system will continue to be behind all others.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Olathe, KS
pros: The benefits are ok.  Most of the employees are friendly and care about patients.  The support staff are very caring and there is some good team work happening in the organization.
cons: T'here is no job security.  If somebody in management doesn't like you, they will fire you for made up reason.  There is no room to move up.  I was told that the chances of them hiring within are very slim.  You have to use PTO for your holidays with out a choice.  You have to use PTO for your first sick day before sick time is used.  Training has been changed to just an email.  Communication from management is terrible.  Management is more like a pack of friends and if you don't fit with them, they will get rid of you.  no matter how good of a job you do.  too  much cronyism.

pros: It has a small Personal atmosphere. Managers and staff are very friendly. On a few occasions, they went out of their way to personally thank me for a task I did. Good place to coast and do your job, then go home. It's growing but it is still low key. If you are a lifer and have no plans to grow, great place.
cons: You have little chance of moving up a ladder. Low turnover. Due to its size, there isn't much room to go anyway. The pay is on par with the pace of the hospital. Low and slow. I wanted to specialize after a year. I was told that if i cross trained in a different department, I would just take that knowledge and go to another hospital. That set the tone for me finding another hospital. The bigger ones give you the opportunity to move be cause of the turnover.

pros: The staff are excellent to work with and very supportive. The physicians for the most part are very easy to get along with. Clean and up to date with technology, i.e. EMR charting.
cons: At first impression, middle management has the appearance of being dysfunctional, unable to improve patient safety, provide adequate staffing, provide equipment when needed, would say one thing but do another. Patient safety is stressed but they continually take away the tools to provide such care. It’s been my experience that upper management does not care and middle management just wants to hold on to their jobs. The middle management that does want to make positive changes usually doesn’t’ last long. They realize that it’s a losing battle and are trapped between upper management, who doesn’t care, and the employees who are trying to make a difference. I was very concerned about my professional license being effected negatively by a management that didn’t want to provide a safe working environment. I cannot work for a company that does not value their patients as people and not numbers! I've seen some very good people leave this place.

pros: Good pay with experience. Most people you work with are friendly and helpful.  Room to expand or work overtime is  available. Patient load is not bad and they go by acuity to make it reasonable to give good care. Great benefits too.
cons: They could update and add more equipment.  Also offer discounts on scrubs and allow different colors.  Also the cycle of pay periods starting on Mondays is confusing.

review_title: Future Cerner IT Analyst - expect to do the job of two FTE's (from a former Cerner Analyst)
pros: Flexible schedule. Some very intelligent co-workers. Most people are OK.
cons: This is in regards to the Cerner Clinical Analysts team: IT is a sweat shop to say teast. Poor and disintegrated processes. All the change request is managed on paper so you are running around trying to get stakeholders, including CFO, to sign them. Poor domain management so it makes testing in non-prod a nightmare. Much work was done via email, thereby unaccounted for, because we weren't allow to tell users to log work orders in the name of 'customer service". Work was distributed unevenly due to clicks and politics within the small IT team. Finance micromanages IT. High turn over. If you work with the Cerner team, especially if you are in an ancillary function (Lab, Pharmnet) expect the work of two full time workers.

pros: Great pay, the staff are friendly

Also they are severely over staffed, I like down time as much as the next person, but not two-three hours of it daily.

review_title: Good time to build something great
pros: The IT department has been through some challenging transitions, but a new CIO is providing forward-thinking leadership. It is a good time to get on board and make a transformational impact. The clinical and business departments appreciate IT, and the people are great to work with. In an organization this size you can work creatively and independently, and you can see how your efforts directly contribute to the well being of your community.
cons: The organization is not open to working remotely. Your first day of sick time comes out of PTO each time you get sick, and new employees accrue PTO slowly.

review_title: OHP Hedge Lane,  My First 7 Weeks

CIO doesn't buffer his Chief Officer coworkers enough to make this position comfortable to endure.   No career path opportunities.  Your only advancement option is to leave the company.  Very cliquish environment that doesn't allow IT managers to discipline their team members because the Chief Officers "like" the team resource.

cons: It's a job. There's always people who make you want to show up again and people who don't.  You learn to make it work. I guess there's one thing:  lots of young people who haven't been in the work force very long who complain too much.

lower pay, no room to move up, bad choices hurt employee benefits.
Bonuses disappeared, benefits cost increased, it became about building pretty buildings instead of taking care of employees.  Have seen nurses about to drop from workloads that are just too much, don't forget the CNA's too!

review_title: Not good if you are a single parent

cons: Great place to work if you don't have kids or if you have a wife or husband that stays at home to care for your kids.  Once I submitted FMLA I was treated different and written up 2 times in a month for little things.  I was overlooked for a promotion and it was given to someone I trained.   It is not a family friendly.

Sweeps everything under the rug. They do not want to hear the bad or to allow anyone else to. The HR dept is terrible! I mean terrible. They do not care or listen and only appreciate the supervisors that are absolutely pathetic.

cons: The "scheduled" lunch hours were ridiculous, 1/2 hour time out on the clock, then clock back in for another half hour to obtain an hour lunch ...nice way to control people from leaving your premises for lunch!

job_title: Biomedical Technician/Connectivity Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good immediate director (still new and getting broken int, but looking to be a great director), great group of fellow biomeds, shop excels in career employees.
cons: poor recognition from beyond immediate director, no advancement opportunities, very little understanding of what a biomed does from management outside shop.  No levels of biomed for promotions.

pros: The pay is competitive. The hospital is highly regarded in the Olathe area, so you should feel good about working for this organization. Overall, the majority of the staff is great to work with and highly knowledgeable. Interactions with patients also tend to lighten the day.
cons:
Due to the departure of a well-respected and well-liked member of the hospital's leadership team, a number of responsibilities have been dispersed to other senior managers. This has created a situation in which at least a few of the individuals who've stepped up to take on new tasks can no longer effectively oversee the original departments they were leading. Naturally, many of these managers are finding it hard to let go of what they were successful at in the first place (especially after learning they know next to nothing about their new responsibilities and encountering failure.) These managers also -- again, naturally -- have a tendency to be overly protective of the job duties they now have to hand over to someone else. In turn, they put far too much pressure on their teams.

Be expected to start from scratch. Despite being hired onto a long-established team, you may quickly find that the departmental processes they have in place are antiquated (even for a hospital.) This organization really wants to be forward thinking and creative with some of its teams, but unfortunately the senior leadership does not support this mentality. When management says they are open to new ideas, that is not necessarily the case. In fact, be prepared to revert back to the old method of doing things.

A number of employees shared with me management's tendency to micro-manage. I found this to be true quickly, and it only got worse from there. From project status and responding to phone calls, to what you wear and the preparation of outlines for every meeting (even the shortest conversations), this organization concentrates on the minutiae. I was often subject to "pop quizzes" about aspects of the hospital organization that were only loosely related to my job at the moment. I was also part of many odd conversations in which my boss questioned my personal integrity because of the frequency with which I checked my voicemail. Bottom line: Employees are not trusted, no matter what your resume says. It may take you several years before you can earn anything close to respect from your direct manager.

The last "con" I will share is that the job that was presented to me was not what I found when I began work. I joined a department that faced an enormous workload, and despite helping that team get out from under this burden, management found a way to change expectations for my role and ultimately be dissatisfied with my performance.

pros: Employees want to do their jobs well.  Organization continues to prosper in competitive market.  Benefit package is comparable to other hospitals.
cons: Constant turnover due to below market wages, poor communication from management, long uncompensated hours expected from salaried employees, and unfriendly work environment.

pros: Absolutely love all my Co works would do anything for them they what  you call a team they aren't at all selfish they are so willing to help anyone that needs it or just learning the job . They are very supportive if your going through a series of bad times they always ask how things are going or how your weekend was and really care about each other here is one little thing that matters to me is when u come in and say good morning to everyone and they respond back good morning how are you
cons: The number one thing I absolutely hate is how hard it is to take off !! When you do your best everyday and all you get Is a good job from your Co works and that's extremely SAD!! if you do need a day off and you asked for it 2 years ago it's going to come down to the last day before your scheduled days off it sucks !!

Main reason why in last 18 months cardiology and orthopedic service line have been completely dismantled. And still most senior management remains employed at Olathe Health.

pros: Strong sense of teamwork withing nursing staff along with great physicians.

pros:

pros: If you are pretty or a physician, great place to work.

pros: The people we work with are encouraging and leadership care about us.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
